title: The Health Benefits of Biotin
author: Regina C Windsor; MPH; RDN
description: Find out whether biotin—a vitamin available in tablets, shampoos, creams, or oils—can help with hair growth and possibly reverse hair loss.
cleaned_text: Skin Health Skin Care & Cleansing Products Hair & Scalp Care The Health Benefits of Biotin A vitamin believed to stimulate hair growth and reverse hair loss By Regina C. Windsor, MPH, RDN Updated on July 20, 2023 Medically reviewed by Melissa Nieves, LND, RD Print Table of Contents View All Table of Contents What Is Biotin? Benefits Side Effects Dosage/Safety What to Look For Frequently Asked Questions Biotin—vitamin B7 or vitamin H—is a micronutrient vital to energy production and other bodily functions. It's found in beef liver, eggs, oats, almonds, spinach, and more. Biotin is also available in supplement form. Companies promote biotin supplements and shampoos for hair health and regrowth. Biotin can positively impact hair thinning and skin issues in people with a confirmed biotin deficiency. This article covers biotin's benefits for your health and hair, its safety, and how to select the right biotin product for you. Verywell / JR Bee What Is Biotin? Biotin is an essential nutrient. An essential nutrient is one that your body can't produce or can't produce enough of and needs to function correctly. So, you need to get biotin from your diet or supplements. It's best to get biotin from the food you eat. Biotin helps your body: Transform your food into energyRegulate cell signals in your bodyManage your gene activity Biotin is available in many common foods. It's mainly stored in your liver. Biotin Benefits Biotin is often touted as a hair loss treatment. However, the research only backs this up if a person has hair loss due to a biotin deficiency. Biotin supplementation is effective in the treatment of biotin deficiency. Check with your healthcare provider before taking a biotin supplement. Hair Growth Some proponents claim that biotin-containing products make your hair stronger and more luxurious. However, science only supports biotin for hair growth if a confirmed biotin deficiency has caused your hair loss. Researchers also note that several factors often help hair regrowth, and biotin supplementation may not be the main factor. Other Studied Conditions Biotin has also been studied for the following conditions: Brittle nails Type 2 diabetes However, the evidence does not support the use of biotin for these conditions. Do You Need More Biotin? Biotin deficiency is rare in the United States. Your healthcare provider can diagnose a biotin deficiency by carefully analyzing your symptoms and lab work. Increasing biotin in your diet or via supplementation can be key in correcting your deficiency. Symptoms of Biotin Deficiency Symptoms of a biotin deficiency include the following: Hair thinning Hair loss Brittle nails A red, scaly rash, usually around the eyes, nose, and mouth Unusual facial fat distribution Skin infections Conjunctivitis Neurological issues—depression, extreme tiredness, hallucinations—in adults Decreased muscle tone, sluggishness, and developmental delay—in infants Seizures If you notice symptoms of biotin deficiency, seek help from your healthcare provider. Causes and Risk Factors You are more likely to experience biotin deficiency if you have the following: Biotinidase deficiency (a rare genetic condition) Chronic alcohol use disorder Pregnancy and breastfeeding Bariatric surgery (ex., laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy) Anorexia or restrictive diets Inflammatory bowel disease (ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease) Celiac disease Regularly eat a lot of raw egg whites—they contain avidin, a protein that binds biotin and prevents its uptake in the body Tobacco use Medications that can lead to biotin deficiency include the following: Anticonvulsants (epilepsy or seizure medicines) Antibiotic use that disrupts gut bacteria 1:11 Click Play to Learn More About Biotin Hair Growth This video has been medically reviewed by Casey Gallagher, MD. What Is Alopecia Areata? Possible Biotin Side Effects Biotin is normally well-tolerated. However, biotin interferes with lab work and can impact the following lab tests: Thyroid levels Vitamin D levels Reproductive hormone tests Cardiac (heart) tests Immunosuppressive drug tests Biotin use has caused the misdiagnosis of hyperthyroidism and Graves' disease, a serious autoimmune thyroid disease. This is due to biotin's impact on thyroid lab work. Check with your healthcare provider before starting a supplement regimen. They may suggest that you stop taking biotin before getting your labs done. Dosage and Safety Biotin is a water-soluble vitamin, meaning excess biotin is usually excreted from your body. The Food and Nutrition Board (FNB) has not established a recommended dietary allowance (RDA) for biotin. However, the following adequate intakes (AI) per day for biotin have been established: Birth to 6 months: 5 micrograms (mcg) per day7 12 months: years: 8 mcg4 to 8 years: 12 mcg9 to 13 20 19 years and older: 30 mcgDuring breastfeeding: 35 mcg People in the United States usually get this amount and more through their diet. Please discuss your biotin use with your healthcare provider, especially before getting your labs done. You may need to stop taking it before getting your lab work, as it can interfere with the results. What to Look For If you're diagnosed with a biotin deficiency, you may be able to correct it with a biotin-rich diet, supplements, or both, depending on what is causing your deficiency. Biotin Supplements Dietary supplements are not regulated the way drugs are in the United States. This means the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) does not approve them for safety and effectiveness before products are marketed. Whenever possible, choose a supplement tested by a trusted third party, such as the following: U.S. Pharmacopeia (USP)ConsumerLab.comNSF.org However, even if supplements are third-party tested, they are not necessarily safe for all or effective in general. Therefore, please talk to your healthcare provider about any supplements you plan to take and ask about potential interactions with other supplements or medications. Biotin-Rich Foods A daily adequate intake (AI) of 30 micrograms (mcg) for adults was established for biotin. Food sources of biotin (in micrograms) include the following: Beef liver, cooked, 3 ounces (30.8)Steel-cut oats, 1/4 cup (8.8)One egg yolk (8)Salmon, pink, canned in water, 3 ounces (5)Pork chop, cooked, 3 ounces (3.8)Sunflower seeds, roasted, 1/4 cup (2.6)Sweet potato, cooked, 1/4 cup (2.4)Almonds, roasted, 1/4 cup (1.5)Spinach, boiled, 1/2 cup (0.5) Summary Biotin supplements are effective for hair loss and skin issues caused by a biotin deficiency. Don't hesitate to contact your healthcare provider if you're concerned about your hair health. Biotin can interfere with your lab work. Please talk with your healthcare provider about stopping it before getting your labs done. Frequently Asked Questions What is biotin? Biotin is a water-soluble vitamin that helps with energy production and so much more. What is biotin good for? Biotin is important for releasing energy from the food you eat. It's also key in different bodily processes, like regulating genes. Does biotin help hair to grow faster? It depends. Research suggests that biotin can help hair regrowth in people with a biotin deficiency. The jury is still out on biotin's ability to grow luxurious locks without a deficiency. Can biotin cause an allergic reaction? Biotin doesn't normally cause allergic reactions. In fact, people deficient in biotin present with a skin rash. And biotin can help clear this up. However, some people may be sensitive to other ingredients in products that also happen to contain biotin. Read your product labels and consult your pharmacist or healthcare provider if you have questions about sensitivities or allergies. 15 Sources Verywell Health uses only high-quality sources, including peer-reviewed studies, to support the facts within our articles.
